description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/3785/documentation

This dataset represents the production of 1 kg of liquid argon. Argon is a colorless and odorless noncombustible gas. It is used in the welding, cutting, and spraying of metals. This dataset represents the production of argon by means of the cryogenic air distillation process, including further crude argon purification. Hydrogen is used to purify the liquefied crude argon. For further compressing, distilling and cooling, electricity is used.;References:;Althaus H.-J., Chudacoff M., Hischier R., Jungbluth N., Osses M. and Primas A. (2007) Life Cycle Inventories of Chemicals. Final report ecoinvent data v2.0 No. 8. Swiss Centre for Life Cycle Inventories, D체bendorf, CH.;H채ussinger, P., Glatthaar, R., Rhode, W., Kick, H., Benkmann, C., Weber, J., Wunschel, H.-J., Stenke, V., Leicht, E. and Stenger, H. 2001. Noble Gases. Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry.;CAMEO Chemicals. Chemical Datasheet, Argon, https://cameochemicals.noaa.gov/chemical/9251 (last accessed on 2017-01-06).

The activity starts with the input of crude liquid argon and hydrogen obtained in an air distillation plant.

This activity ends with the production of 1 kg of liquid argon with a purity of 99.999%. The dataset neglects the small amount of waste gas containing mainly H2O, N2 and non-oxidized H2. Other emissions to air and water are not considered. The dataset includes the electricity for processing, and hydrogen for catalytic burning of oxygen. An approximation for additional infrastructure is made.

processDocumentation.technologyDescription: The technology represented in this dataset is the catalytic burning of oxygen impurities in argon with hydrogen.;Pure commercial argon (99.999% Ar) is purified from crude argon (96-98% Ar, 2-4% O2, <1% N2) in further rectification columns and catalytic removal of the remaining oxygen impurities with hydrogen. ;The crude argon is heated in a heat exchanger and compressed to 4-6 bar. Then the deoxygenating of the stream with hydrogen takes place and the stream is cooled from 950 째C to 15 째C. After further cooling in the heat exchanger, pure argon is separated from excess hydrogen in a distillation column.;It is also possible to pass the crude argon through further rectifying columns and achieve an impurity of only 10 ppm without the use of hydrogen. In this case the consumption of hydrogen would be negligible, but the electricity demand would probably be significant. This alternative purification process is not considered in this inventory. The figure below gives a simplified scheme of the purifying process for crude argon.;Reference: Personal communication, Richard Troxler, Pangas AG Switzerland, 16.01.2002.

exchanges.description: Argon (Ar) is a monatomic, chemically inert gas composing slightly less than 0.93% by volume of the air. Argon is colourless, odourless, tasteless, non-corrosive, non-flammable, and non-toxic. Argon is the most abundant and most used of the noble gases. Commercial argon is the product of cryogenic air separation.

exchanges.description: Estimated value. The energy required for the purification step of crude argon is needed for the catalytic removal of the oxygen impurities and further cooling and distilling of the pure argon. According to the source, the energy consumption in the argon purifying unit is around 0.667 MJ per kg of liquid argon (exergy loss due to the purification step). Thereof, 75% or 0.5 MJ/kg is needed in the form of hydrogen (gross calorific value), which is used to remove the oxygen impurities. The remaining 0.167 MJ/kg are used for further process steps (compressing, distillation, heat exchanger losses) and are accounted as additional power consumption in the form of electricity.
